transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Hello everyone. Today we're going to talk about growth mindset.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: What's that?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Growth mindset is the idea that you can get better at things through effort and practice.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Like studying more?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, exactly. So the main point is that effort matters. If you work hard, you can improve.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let me read you the definition from the manual. Growth mindset is the belief that abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work. This view creates a love of learning and resilience.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: But some people are just naturally smarter, right?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Well, people do have different starting points, but the key is you can improve from wherever you start. Anyway, let's move on.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: The curriculum says I should tell you that effort matters more than talent. So remember that - effort is important.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: I failed my math test even though I studied.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Okay, that's tough. But with growth mindset, you can try again. Next time study more or differently.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: How do I know what to do differently?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: You just have to figure out what works for you. Everyone's different.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: So, to summarize: growth mindset means you can improve. Fixed mindset means you think you can't. You should have a growth mindset.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: Can you give us an example?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Sure. Like, if you're bad at something, instead of saying 'I'm bad at this,' you say 'I'm not good at this yet.' The word 'yet' is important.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: That makes sense.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Good. So everyone understand? Great. Let's continue.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: According to the research, the brain can change. It's kind of like a muscle in that way. When you practice, you get better.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: So anyone can be good at anything?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Well, you can improve at anything. That's the main idea here.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: I've been really stressed about exams.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Stress is normal. You know what helps me? I make sure to exercise and get enough sleep. Also, maybe try some breathing exercises or meditation. Those can really help with stress management.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: Do you have any specific techniques?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: There are lots of apps for meditation. And for sleep, try to avoid screens before bed. Good sleep hygiene is really important for academic performance.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: What about anxiety medication?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That's something you'd need to talk to a doctor about. I can't really advise on that. But lifestyle changes like exercise can help too.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: My parents put a lot of pressure on me to get good grades.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That's a common issue. Parent pressure can be difficult. Have you tried talking to them about how you feel? Communication is important in families. Sometimes parents don't realize the impact of their expectations.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: What should I say to them?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Just be honest about your feelings. Tell them you're trying your best. Anyway, we should probably get back to growth mindset.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: So, where were we? Right, growth mindset. The important thing to remember is that you can develop your abilities. That's really the core message.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Is there anything we should practice this week?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, good question. Try to notice when you have negative thoughts about your abilities. Then try to reframe them more positively with a growth mindset perspective.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: Like what?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Like if you think 'I'm terrible at science,' change it to 'I'm still learning science.' Something like that.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Does everyone understand the concept now? Any questions?

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: I think I get it.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Yeah, makes sense.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Okay good. So the main points are: effort matters, you can improve through practice, and don't have a fixed mindset. Those are the key takeaways.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let me check my notes... yes, I think we've covered everything. Growth mindset is about believing you can develop your abilities. That's what you need to remember.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: This was helpful.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Great. I'm glad you found it useful.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: So for next week, just try to apply this mindset to your studies. When things get hard, remember that you can improve with effort.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Will we talk about this more next time?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: We'll be moving on to a new topic, but you can always bring up questions about growth mindset if you have them.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Alright, I think that covers it. Thank you for your attention today. See you next session.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Thanks.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: You're welcome. Have a good week everyone.
